user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_FileSysMountVolume_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_FileSysMountVolume_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    OS_filesys_internal_record_t *local;
    struct stat                   stat_buf;

    local = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_filesys_table, *token);

    /*
     * This will do a mkdir() for the mount point if it does
     * not already exist.
     */
    if (stat(local->system_mountpt, &stat_buf) != 0)
    {
        if (mkdir(local->system_mountpt, 0700) < 0)
        {
            OS_DEBUG("ERROR: Cannot create mount point %s: %s", local->system_mountpt, strerror(errno));
            return OS_FS_ERR_DRIVE_NOT_CREATED;
        }
    }
    else if (!S_ISDIR(stat_buf.st_mode))
    {
        OS_DEBUG("ERROR: Volume %s exists and is not a directory", local->system_mountpt);
        return OS_FS_ERR_DRIVE_NOT_CREATED;
    }

    /*
     * NOTE: The mount() system call could be used here to actually
     * mount a disk, if warranted.  For all current POSIX-based PSPs,
     * this is not needed, because the volumes are all pre-mounted
     * through the system init before OSAL starts.
     *
     * For volatile filesystems (ramdisk) these were created within
     * a temp filesystem, so all that is needed is to ensure the
     * mount point exists.  For any other FS type, trigger an
     * error to indicate that it is not implemented in this OSAL.
     */
    if (local->fstype != OS_FILESYS_TYPE_VOLATILE_DISK && local->fstype != OS_FILESYS_TYPE_FS_BASED)
    {
        /* the mount command is not implemented for this FS type */
        return OS_ERR_NOT_IMPLEMENTED;
    }

    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: Other fragments in the function do not modify the function parameter. There are no assignments to the parameter variable 'token' anywhere else in the function, nor any pointer arithmetic or increments on it. All subsequent uses operate on the local variable 'local' or on members of the object pointed to by 'local' (e.g. local->system_mountpt, local->fstype), or call library functions (stat, mkdir, strerror) that do not alter the parameter. The only potential concern is the function parameter declaration and the macro invocation: the declaration shows a pointer parameter and the macro call dereferences it (*token). The dereference as used in the code reads the token value; however the macro OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET could, depending on its definition, modify its argument or cast away const. Therefore the signature and the macro call should be examined. All other code does not modify the function parameter and thus does not require investigation for MISRA C:2023 Rule 17.8.
